The  principal  objective  of  the  Program  is  to  provide  support  for  the
Government’s  comprehensive  reform  agenda  for  strengthening  the
health sector. Its scope includes five policy priority areas: (i) develop
sustainable financing for the health sector; (ii) strengthen capacity in
health  sector  management;  (iii)  strengthen  quality  assurance  and
public  health  regulatory  functions;  (iv)  adjust  imbalances  in  human
resources for health; and (v) strengthen PHC through selective PHC
interventions and expansion of priority services.

The ADB Loan

Loan Amount and

Program Period
and Tranching

A  loan  of  $10.0  million  is  proposed  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds
resources.  The  loan  will  have  a  repayment  period  of  24  years,
including a grace period of 8 years. An interest rate of 1 percent will
be  charged  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5  percent  per
annum thereafter, and other terms and conditions in accordance with
the Loan Agreement.

The  Program  will  cover  five  years  (FY2001-FY2005).  The  proposed
loan  is  to  be  disbursed  in  two  tranches.  The  first  tranche  of  $5.0
million  will  be  made  available  upon  loan  effectiveness,  while  the
second tranche, also for $5.0 million, will be made available following
the  Government’s  compliance  with  the  conditions  set  for  its  release.
The Program will be completed by June 2005.

 I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a  proposed

1.
loan to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the Health Care Reform Program.

I.

THE PROPOSAL

II.

INTRODUCTION

In  response  to  a  request  of  the  Royal  Government  of  Bhutan,  the  Asian  Development
2.
Bank  (ADB)  provided  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  in  1999  to  help  develop  a
policy reform agenda that would strengthen the overall efficiency of the health sector in Bhutan.1
The TA reviewed the health sector in Bhutan, including its key issues and constraints, to identify
priority  areas  for  development.  The  TA  also  assessed  the  options  for  promoting  sustainable
financing  for  health  services  including  the  introduction  of  a  Bhutan  Health  Trust  Fund  (BHTF)
that would enable the Government to meet the demands of economic growth and diversification.
During  TA  implementation,  field  surveys,  focus  group  discussions,  and  consultations  with  key
stakeholders, including major aid agencies, were conducted and the results were used to design
the Health Care Reform Program. A poverty impact assessment of the Program was prepared,
which  was  improved  by  the  Fact-Finding  Mission  from  20  March-5  April  2000.  The  Appraisal
Mission,2 which visited Bhutan from 24 May-2 June 2000, held further consultations with major
stakeholders  and  conducted  an  information-sharing  workshop  in  which  various  Government
ministries,  district  and  health  workers,  and  major  aid  agencies  participated.  The  Program
framework was subsequently updated and refined as shown in Appendix 1.

III.

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT

A.

Development Objectives, Strategy and Plans

3.
The  Human  Development  Index  of  the  United  Nations  Development  Programme  ranks
Bhutan  142nd  of  174  countries.3  Over  85  percent  of  the  population  reside  in  rural  areas,  and
most  of  the  population  depend  on  subsistence  agriculture.  There  are  wide  variations  in
household  income  depending  on  the  geographic  area.  Although  the  low  Bhutanese  income
generally reflects widespread income poverty, the kind of abject poverty seen in some parts of
Asia as a result of such low incomes is not evident in Bhutan. The Government’s social welfare
policies over many years have focused on promoting human development and have resulted in
relatively widespread social well-being. Women in Bhutan generally have a much higher status
than their counterparts in many other countries in South Asia. Coverage of the population with
clean water and access to latrines continues to increase concomitant with the integration of rural
water  and  sanitation  projects  as  part  of  the  country’s  health  program.  As  such,  the  entire
population is expected to gain access to potable water by the end of the Eighth Five-Year Plan
or the Eighth Plan (FY1998-FY2002).

4.
Recent investments in the education sector have resulted in significant improvements in
educational  status  and  literacy,  especially  for  girls,  and  given  ongoing  investments,  this  trend
will continue. The primary school enrolment rate is 72 percent and has been increasing steadily.

1 TA 3186-BHU: Health Care Financing and Reform Program, for $150,000, approved on 16 April 1999.
2 The Mission comprised E.A. Cua, Senior Project Specialist and Mission Leader and R. Vankina, Counsel, and was

assisted by S.W. Handayani, Social Development Specialist.

3 UNDP, Human Development Report, 2000.

 2

Adult  literacy  has  significantly  improved  from  23  percent  in  1980  to  54  percent  in  1996;
however, this conceals the much lower literacy rate of 28 percent for women. Moreover, limited
tertiary  education  opportunities  and  few  job  openings  in  the  service  and  Government  sectors
have led to increasing concerns regarding employment opportunities for high school graduates.

5.
Demographic  factors  also  play  a  significant  role  in  determining  patterns  of  health  and
disease. In 1997, the population of Bhutan was estimated at 618,000 and growing at an annual
rate  of  3.1  percent.  This  high  rate  of  population  growth,  which  increased  from  2.0  percent  in
1984,  is  primarily  attributed  to  a  rapid  decline  in  mortality.  This  rate  of  growth  will  result  in  a
doubling of the population in 20 years, and will have a major impact on the demand for health
services. The Government has identified population growth as a major development issue and
is active in population planning activities. Recent intensification of family planning activities has
probably  resulted  in  a  significant  increase  in  the  contraceptive  prevalence  rate  and  should
reduce fertility and population growth rates.

6.
There has been a significant increase in internal rural-to-urban migration during the past
20  years  as  shown  by  the  declining  share  of  rural  population  from  95  percent  in  1980  to  the
current  85  percent  of  the  total  population.  This  migration  is  likely  to  continue  and  will  affect
demand  for  health  services.  Unofficial  immigration  and  traffic  across  the  relatively  porous
southern and eastern borders may affect utilization of services and patterns of disease as well
(communicable diseases such as tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS4 are of primary concern).

7.
Development efforts in Bhutan have also usually involved the participation of the various
sectors  of  society.  This  approach  has  been  instrumental  in  promoting  good  governance  and
improving social development. In line with the development philosophy of the Government, the
health and education sectors comprise over one quarter of public spending. Health alone is now
over  11  percent  of  the  total,  an  increase  from  6.5  percent  in  1992/93.  Total  health  care
expenditures  represent  about  4.0  percent  of  GDP,  comparing  favorably  with  other  DMCs  in
South and South East Asia.

B.

Recent Economic Performance and Prospects

Bhutan’s  traditional  economy,  which  is  based  on  subsistence  agriculture  and  barter
8.
trade, began to diversify in the 1980s when gross domestic product (GDP) growth accelerated,
reaching  8  percent  per  year.  Economic  growth  and  prudent  fiscal  management  have  enabled
domestic  revenues  to  adequately  cover  all  recurrent  costs  in  almost  every  year  since  1993.
However  the  tax  base  is  still  limited,  and  the  country  relies  heavily  on  external  assistance  to
fund  its  development  programs,  particularly  capital  expenditures.  Although  the  Government
plans to introduce a personal income tax in 2001 once the required legislation is completed, the
gains from this new tax mechanism are not expected to be realized for some time.

9.
The  key  source  of  growth  in  Bhutan’s  economy  has  been  hydroelectric  power,  the
development  of  which  has  been  largely  funded  by  assistance  from  India.  Revenues  from  the
hydroelectric  power  plants  comprise  40  percent  of  total  Government  current  revenues;  the
expected  tripling  of  production  should  eventually  reduce  the  Government’s  dependence  on
international  assistance.  The  trade  balance  shows  a  significant  dependence  on  India,  for  both
trade  and  assistance.  Over  90  percent  of  exports  are  normally  to  India,  and  70  percent  of
imports originate from India. India provides more than half of the country’s total grant assistance
and a third of its total public external debt in 1999.

4 HIV/AIDS refers to human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

 3

10.
Prudent  fiscal  management  notwithstanding,  Bhutan  will  need  to  address  certain
fundamental issues and potential risks: (i) the fragile dependence on energy exports to India as
the  single  most  important  source  of  Government  revenue;  (ii)  limited  and  structurally  weak
domestic revenue base that may not be able to cover rising recurrent expenditures to maintain
physical  and  social  infrastructure,  and  specific  programs;  (iii)  the  possible  slowdown  of  the
inflow of grants and concessional loans; and (iv) increasing debt-service requirements for loans
used to finance new power projects. Key socioeconomic indicators are presented in Appendix 2.

A.

Background and Recent Performance

IV.

THE SECTOR

11.
The  development  of  modern  health  systems  and  health  infrastructure  in  Bhutan
commenced during the early 1960s. Prior to this, access to western medical services, provided
by  a  few  Indian-trained  Bhutanese  physicians,  was  limited.  The  majority  of  the  population
utilized  traditional  medical  services  and  obtained  spiritual  assistance  offered  by  religious
institutions  for  treatment  of  illness.  While  allopathic  medical  services  continue  to  expand,
traditional medicine is still recognized as the official medical tradition in Bhutan and is included
in the national health system.

12.
The Government provides essentially all modern medical services in the country, apart
from that provided by a few private pharmacy outlets in the main towns. The health system is
based  on  the  principles  of  primary  health  care  (PHC),  and  provides  integrated  curative,
preventive, and promotive services. This approach targets vulnerable groups (the poor, women,
children,  and  rural  populations)  through  the  establishment  of  basic  health  units  (BHUs)
nationwide,  and  through  the  delivery  of  services  appropriate  for  these  groups  (communicable
disease  control;  reproductive  health  services  including  family  planning,  immunization,  water,
and sanitation; and provision of essential drugs). This focus on basic health services is a critical
aspect of social development and poverty reduction, and has proved to be an effective strategy
for reaching out to the thinly scattered settlements throughout the country’s mountainous terrain.
Selected data on Bhutan’s health sector are shown in Appendix 3.

1.

Health Status

Huge strides have been made, especially since the 1980s, in improving the health status
13.
of the Bhutanese population. Life expectancy at birth, 48 years in 1984, rose dramatically to 66
years  in  1994.  Marked  improvement  is  evident  in  infant  and  under-five  mortality  rates,  and
significantly, there is no gender disparity in these rates. Childhood immunization coverage has
been  generally  sustained  at  over  80  percent  since  1990.  No  cases  of  poliomyelitis  have  been
diagnosed  since  1986  and  the  last  neonatal  tetanus  death  occurred  in  1994.  No  other  deaths
from  vaccine-preventable  diseases  have  been  reported  since  1994.5  The  maternal  mortality
rate, 770 per 100,000 live births in 1984, dropped to 380 in 1994. Iodine deficiency disorder, a
major problem a decade ago is now virtually eliminated, and leprosy is almost eradicated. The
remarkable  improvement  in  health  indicators  has  been  attributed  to  the  Government’s

5 Mortality reporting is of questionable completeness and quality in Bhutan; nevertheless, that there have been no
reported deaths is a significant improvement over past performance. In addition, using data on mortality rates for
comparative purposes should be done with caution, given the country’s small population base.

 4

continuing  commitment  to  provide  universal  access  to  a  package  of  minimum  essential  health
services under its health-for-all objective.

2.

Health Infrastructure

14.
Health  services  are  delivered  through  a  four-tier  network  consisting  of  the  national
referral hospital, the regional referral hospitals, the district hospitals, and BHUs. The BHU is a
primary  level  institution  in  the  health  care  system  and  caters  to  a  population  of  about  2,500-
5,000. The standard staff complement of a BHU comprises a health assistant, an auxiliary nurse
midwife, and a basic health worker. Each BHU has an average of 3-6 outreach clinics (ORCs)
through which services to the most distant villages are delivered, at present on a once-a-month
basis.  These  ORCs,  to  a  large  extent  funded  by  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  (UNICEF),
have  been  instrumental  in  increasing  access  to  services;  it  is  anticipated  that  activities  will  be
carried out in these posts more frequently in the future. To date, there are 145 BHUs across the
country; together with their ORCs, they enable the Government to provide basic health services
to about 90 percent of the population. The Government intends to consolidate and strengthen its
health  infrastructure  during  the  Eighth  Plan  with  an  additional  15  BHUs  to  be  constructed  by
2002.

15.
District  hospitals  are  the  first-level  referral  institutions  and  are  equipped  to  provide
curative,  promotive,  preventive,  and  emergency  services.  There  are  currently  28  district
hospitals  (including  the  three  regional  referral  hospitals),  14  of  which  have  indigenous  units.
Regional  referral  hospitals  are  the  second-level  referral  hospitals  and  provide  specialist
services.  At  the  national  level  is  the  Jigme  Dorji  Wangchuck  National  Referral  Hospital
(JDWNRH), which also serves as the regional referral hospital for the western region.

3.

Human Resources for Health

16. While the Government continues to need the services of expatriate physicians, there is a
gradual shift to reliance on nationals. At present, only 8 of the 98 physicians practicing in Bhutan
are expatriates. The Government is committed to providing a totally Bhutanese health staff as
soon  as  possible.  The  establishment  of  the  Royal  Institute  of  Health  Sciences  (RIHS)  in  1974
was the first step in the development of self-reliance in human resources. Apart from physicians,
the very few baccalaureate-educated health workers, and certain specialized health personnel,
training  of  health  staff  in  Bhutan  is  carried  out  by  RIHS.  In  addition  to  the  clinical  staff,  RIHS
trains X-ray, pharmacy, laboratory, dental, and physiotherapy technicians, as well as opticians
and ophthalmic assistants.

17.
The foundation of the health system is the nurse and other paramedic staff: the general
nurse  midwife,  health  assistant,  auxiliary  nurse  midwife,  assistant  nurse,  and  basic  health
worker.  They  are  generally  attached  to  the  BHUs  and  assisted  by  village  health  workers,
volunteers  who  motivate  the  communities,  provide  a  link  between  the  health  services  and  the
community, and provide simple treatments.

The  Royal  Civil  Service  Commission  (RCSC)  is  responsible  for  human  resource
18.
planning, and for selecting candidates for both national and international training. The number of
training  positions  is  determined  based  on  the  Master  Plan  for  Human  Resources,  which  was
developed in FY1995. Since then, the master plan has not been updated, and there is no recent
official report on projected staffing needs.

 5

4.

Health Services Management and Planning

19.
The  Government  has  adopted  the  policy  of  decentralization  as  a  major  objective  in
managing  the  delivery  of  health  services.  Commencing  in  1981,  the  district  (dzongkhag)
administrations  were  made  entirely  responsible  for  all  health  services,  excluding  referral
hospitals  and  training  institutions.  In  addition,  management  of  health  services  is  anchored  on
two strategic approaches: the integration of health services and the empowerment of peripheral
health  workers.  Thus,  disease-specific  activities  are  being  addressed  in  an  integrated  fashion
not through vertical health programs requiring separate health workers and facilities. BHU staff
help  determine  the  relevance  of  national  programs  in  the  local  context  and  set  their  program
priorities in consultation with the district health supervisory officer.

Planning  in  the  health  sector  comprises  three-linked  stages:  the  five-year  plan,  the
20.
annual plan, and the planning of day-to-day activities. It follows a bottom-up process with local
administrations  preparing  proposals  that  are  submitted  to  the  Policy  and  Planning  Division
(PPD)  of  the  Ministry  of  Health  and  Education  (MOHE).  Health  workers  actively  participate  in
developing annual operational plans. This participatory planning process culminates every year
with the annual health conference which is attended by all district health medical officers, and
supervisors,  engineers,  and  concerned  staff  of  MOHE  and  national-level,  health-related
institutes.  The  annual  health  conference  has  become  a  very  useful  forum  for  sharing
experiences,  reviewing  progress  of  health  programs,  receiving  feedback  from  the  field,
identifying  problems  and  issues,  and  providing  inputs  for  the  preparation  of  health  sector
program strategies and plans. This annual interaction between policymakers and field workers
in  Bhutan  has  substantially  contributed  to  the  development  of  a  health  system  based  on
transparency  and  accountability,  and  demonstrates  the  priority  the  Government  accords  to
improving the health status of the people.

5.

Health Expenditures and Financing

21.
Health  services  and  drugs  are  generally  provided  free-of-charge  for  nationals,  and
nonnationals  with  work  permits.  The  Government  also  shoulders  the  costs  of  tertiary  care
incurred  by  patients  who  cannot  be  treated  within  the  country  and  are  referred  for  treatment
either in India or Thailand. The public health system is largely financed by the Government and
international aid and to a small extent, by a contribution by civil servants representing 1 percent
of  their  salaries  (estimated  to  meet  only  1.2  percent  of  total  health  expenditures).  Recently,
some direct user charges were introduced for private cabins, medical certificates, some dental
procedures  and  diagnostics  in  hospital  facilities.  On  the  average,  external  assistance  has
accounted  for  43  percent  of  total  health  expenditures  annually  during  1995-1998,  and  was
estimated to meet 65 percent of public expenditures in health care in FY1999. Although most of
this assistance is for capital expenditures, a considerable portion is for recurrent expenditures,
causing concern for sustained financing of the sector.

22. Within  the  public  health  sector,  the  major  expenditure  has  been  in  capital  investment
(over  45  percent  of  total  expenditures)  reflecting  the  ongoing  investment  in  expanding  health
service  infrastructure.  Recurrent  expenditures  have  been  increasing  each  year,  although  their
share  of  total  health  expenditures  has  been  declining  with  the  recent  surge  in  capital
expenditures. By component, personnel cost is the most important area of recurrent expenditure
in the health sector. Total personnel costs are equal to 36 percent of recurrent costs, and are
rising  in  both  absolute  and  relative  terms  as  the  Government  fills  human  resources  gaps  still
faced  by  the  sector.  Another  major  expenditure  item,  drug  and  nondrug  medical  supplies  (9.5
percent of total expenditures) has been shrinking in real terms in recent years.

 6

B.

Constraints and Issues

23.
The  huge  strides  made  in  improving  health  status  notwithstanding,  there  are  evident
deficiencies.  Although  investments  in  infrastructure  development  could  partially  address
geographic  and  other  physical  constraints,  capacity-building  efforts  and  policy  reforms  are
critically  needed  to  enhance  efficiency  and  quality  of  health  care  delivery,  and  to  ensure
sustainable  financing  of  the  sector.  The  high  population  growth  rate  will  place  additional
pressure on health care financing, where recurrent expenditures have been rising substantially.
In  addition,  the  demographic  transition  (a  shift  to  an  older  population  structure)  will  result  in  a
shift from a pattern of morbidity and mortality dominated by infectious diseases, to a pattern in
which  chronic  degenerative  diseases  predominate.  Economic  development  will  also  lead  to
greater  demand  for  a  wider  range  of  services  currently  not  available.  These  imply  that  new
demands  will  be  put  on  existing  human  resources,  which  currently  are  critically  inadequate  in
many  areas.  Public  health  concerns  have  also  emerged  on  the  use  of  alcohol  and  betel,
increased smoking, and the potential spread of HIV/AIDS. For the Government to continue its
significant progress in improving the health status of the population, reforms will be needed to
address  current  weaknesses  and  to  prepare  for  emerging  and  future  challenges.  These  will
necessarily  involve  measures  to  ensure  financial  strength,  improve  management  practices,
strengthen  human  resources  for  health,  and  strengthen  the  regulatory  framework  for  public
health including the development of sound environmental policies.

1. 

Health Sector Financing

Health in Bhutan is an import-intensive sector that requires substantial foreign currency
24.
to finance essential drugs, vaccines, equipment, other medical supplies and training. In addition,
there  is  a  growing  concern  about  the  accelerated  rise  in  number  and  cost  of  out-of-country
referrals,  mainly  because  of  the  increase  of  noncommunicable  diseases  such  as  cancer.  For
instance, the cost of out-of-country treatment increased by more than three times during 1994-
1999;  out-of-country  referrals  now  account  for  5  percent  of  total  health  care  expenditures.  As
this  trend  and  the  increase  in  personnel  costs  continue,  without  increasing  budgetary
commitments,  other  areas  of  the  budget,  such  as  medical  supplies,  will  continue  to  contract.
Current  health  expenditure  patterns  have  also  revealed  inefficiencies  in  the  use  of  health
services  due  to  the  non-compliance  with  the  referral  system,  with  patients  bypassing  primary
health facilities and referring themselves to district and national hospitals. In certain cases, this
practice  is  exacerbated  by  the  poor  prescription  and  extensive  use  of  free,  nonessential,  and
low-impact drugs, such as paracetamol and antacids and the irrational use of antibiotics. Such
practices have contributed to the increase in health expenditures on nonessential drugs.

25.
The dependence on international aid to meet rising health expenditures is considerable,
but  cannot  be  taken  for  granted  over  the  long  term.  Although  the  Government  expects  to
generate additional revenues through the export of hydropower and levy of personal income tax,
the health sector will still have to compete with other sectors for its share of the national budget.
Thus,  longer  term,  sustainable  solutions  to  financing  health  sector  import  requirements  are
essential and should now be explored by the Government. In addition, measures to improve the
efficient  use  of  resources  and  to  contain  costs  should  be  introduced  to  promote  more  rational
use  of  health  services  and  reduce  wastage.  The  adoption  of  a  social  insurance  scheme  has
been deemed inappropriate at this stage given current conditions, such as low GDP per capita,
lack  of  a  large  enough  formal  wage  and  private  sector,  and  the  still  predominantly  rural  and
dispersed population. The costs of administering a scheme with limited population coverage are
high.  However,  the  Government  is  pursuing  several  financing  options  including  (i)  the  recent

 7

creation of a BHTF as a sustainable financing mechanism to meet future import requirements of
vaccines,  essential  drugs,  and  new  technologies;  and  (ii)  the  expansion  of  selected  user
charges for other nonessential services.

2. 

Health Management and Planning

26.
Although  the  health  management  system  has  been  strengthened  and  participatory
planning processes firmly established particularly with external assistance, there remains room
for  improvement  to  ensure  the  equity  and  quality  aspects  of  health  care.  Decentralized  health
management  could  become  even  more  effective  when  this  is  accompanied  by  strong
institutional  capacity,  integrated  program  reporting,  and  monitoring  mechanisms  at  the  central
level. The existing health management information system (HMIS) functions well in comparison
with information systems in many other countries. However, the HMIS, which has evolved over
the years in an ad hoc fashion, suffers from duplication, complexity, lack of qualitative data and
analysis,  and  other  inconsistencies.  While  health  programs  and  plans  have  objectives  with
measurable and time-limited targets, deficiencies in the HMIS have undermined MOHE’s ability
to track progress in achieving these targets.

27.
In  addition,  reports  on  some  health  programs,  such  as  the  expanded  program  for
immunization, tuberculosis, and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) are separately prepared.
Data  need  to  be  disaggregated  by  age,  gender,  and  economic  and  minority  group,  and  if
population size warrants, by geographic area. A comprehensive strategic framework is needed
to guide policy planning and monitoring functions, and to update the HMIS for better targeting of
health  programs  and  beneficiaries.  There  is  also  a  need  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  PPD,
which  currently  lacks  adequate  staff  to  carry  out  its  planning,  monitoring  and  evaluation
functions.

28.
Expenditure  reporting  requirements  are  also  numerous  due  to  the  various  funding
agencies in the health sector; however, the current system for financial reporting does not link
expenditures  to  output  of  the  programs  and  delivery  system.  The  current  budgetary  reporting
system is based on actual cash flows and does not cover the in-kind assistance of aid agencies.
It needs to be improved to take account of the magnitude of such a component and to enable a
more accurate evaluation of program delivery based on total investments, including donations in
kind.  Streamlining  sector  financial  management  would  complement  capacity-building  efforts  in
this area.

3. 

Human Resources for Health

29.
The shortage of human resources is a problem that affects all sectors in Bhutan. Despite
Government  efforts  to  provide  out-of-country  training  since  the  1960s,  there  remain  critical
shortages  in  many  areas;  this  is  particularly  evident  in  the  health  sector  where  there  is  a
continued  reliance  on  expatriates  and  out-of-country  treatment  for  specialist  care.  RCSC  has
prepared  a  human  resource  development  (HRD)  master  plan  for  the  Eighth  Plan  period  with
inputs  from  the  various  sectors.  These  sector  plans  were  to  be  updated  annually,  but  this
revision  has  yet  to  be  completed  by  MOHE.  As  personnel  are  the  key  component  of  health
expenditures, changes in human resource planning have major impacts on overall expenditures.
The  master  plan  is  also  used  by  RCSC  to  plan  investments  in  out-of-country  undergraduate
education. If the plan does not present an accurate reflection of the goals of the health sector,
resources  can  be  wasted  by  investing  in  the  wrong  areas.  Updating  of  the  HRD  plan  for  the
health sector is long overdue.

 8

Certain gender bias exists in the selection and career structure of paramedical workers.
30.
By definition, the health assistant, who has the supervisory role at the BHU, is male. This policy
was adopted due to difficulty assigning female health assistants in remote areas where travel to
isolated  villages  is  required.  Thus,  at  present  females  cannot  apply  for  training  as  a  health
assistant;  therefore  they  are  automatically  prevented  from  advancing  to  the  next  position  of
district health supervisory officer. This lack of equal opportunity in career and training needs to
be addressed when revising the HRD plan for the health sector. At the community level, there is
a need to promote the role of village health worker to help prevent its numbers from declining
and to encourage more community participation.

4. 

Quality Assurance and Public Health Regulations

MOHE  has  a  well-established  system  of  supervision  of  BHUs  and  district  hospitals.
31.
However a significant weakness is evident in the lack of standardized guidelines and checklists.
Apart from this system for health facility supervision, quality assurance is lacking for the health
system as a whole. There is a need, therefore, to develop the institutional capacity for promoting
quality assurance.

32.
Bhutan’s traditional and consensual society relies on a relatively informal system of rules
governing  all  aspects  of  comportment  of  the  population.  Bhutan’s  legal  system  is  evolving  a
system of formal and objective law. A number of laws, regulations, resolutions, endorsements,
and  circulars  with  relevance  to  the  health  sector  exist;  they  are  promulgated  by  various
ministries, including MOHE, and more peripheral levels of government. However, little regulation
exists for several issues of great public health importance. For instance, it is well known that the
most  effective  intervention  to  ensure  the  health  of  the  newborn  and  infant  is  exclusive  breast-
feeding.  While  breast-milk  substitutes  are  occasionally  required,  their  indiscriminate  use
invariably  results  in  increased  rates  of  diarrhea  and  increased  infant  mortality.  In  Bhutan,
diarrhea  remains  the  second  leading  cause  of  infant  mortality.  Marketing  of  these  products
needs to be regulated to ensure that breast-feeding is promoted, and that caregivers are aware
of the dangers of using substitutes.

33.
Training  of  health  professionals  both  in  Bhutan  and  out-of-country  is  a  top  priority.
However, to date, there is no system of regulation of professional competence (including basic
training  and  continuing  education)  of  health  workers  at  any  level;  nor  are  there  guidelines
related to the ethical standards of the professions. Standardization of professional competence
and conduct is crucial to the safe and effective functioning of a health system.

34.
Other  specific  areas  of  great  public  health  importance  for  which  little  regulation  exists
include occupational health and safety, substance abuse (alcohol, tobacco, and betel), disposal
of medical waste, environmental health related to urban development, and regulation of private
sector  health  services  (pharmacies,  diagnostic  facilities,  and  dental  and  eye  services).  The
Ministry of Trade and Industry has promulgated some regulations regarding the sale of alcohol
and pharmaceuticals, but these are of relatively limited scope.

Until recently, laws, regulations, and other legal documents, although widely understood,
35.
have  not  been  compiled,  catalogued  and  maintained.  Also,  while  these  legal  documents  may
have  significant  health  ramifications,  there  is  no  system  in  place  to  ensure  the  participation  of
the health sector in their formulation. Nor is there a formal mechanism to ensure that MOHE is
aware  of  their  existence.  The  Government  needs  to  overcome  this  institutional  weakness  in
order to strengthen its regulatory function in the health sector.

 9

5. 

Gaps in Primary Health Care

36.
The huge program of infrastructure development over the past decade has resulted in a
near  optimum  level  of  health  infrastructure  at  the  primary  level.  The  number  of  district  and
regional  referral  hospitals  has  significantly  increased  and  their  capacity  improved.  However,
there  are  certain  gaps  and  other  weaknesses  in  PHC6  which  the  Government  must  overcome
since  PHC  is  the  most  effective  and  direct  intervention  for  protecting  the  poor  and  other
vulnerable  groups.  The  high  population  growth  rate  implies  that  reproductive  health  and
immunization  programs  deserve  particular  attention  to  benefit  women  and  children.  Currently,
PHC  accounts  for  about  50  percent  of  total  recurrent  health  expenditures  (by  level),  and
budgetary  support  must  not  be  allowed  to  fall  below  this  level  if  future  gains  are  to  be
accomplished. It is thus crucial for the Government to address some of the specific weaknesses
identified  in  the  PHC  system.  The  maternal  mortality  rate,  halved  between  1984  and  1994,  is
still too high at 380; much of this mortality is due to the lack of adequate obstetrical care. Access
to reproductive health services including essential obstetrical care and clinical family planning is
currently  limited  by  the  lack  of  staff  trained  in  surgery  and  anesthesia.  Improvements  in  these
services  would  help  to  reduce  maternal  morbidity  and  mortality.  Recent  investigations  by  the
Epidemiology and Research Unit have found that about 15 percent of hospital deliveries are of
low  birth  weight,  and  just  under  20  percent  of  under-fives  exhibit  moderate  to  severe
malnutrition.  Also,  there  is  a  high  prevalence  of  iron  deficiency  and  subclinical  vitamin  A
deficiency.

37.
As  in  most  developing  countries,  the  burden  of  infectious  disease  is  high.  Acute
respiratory  tract  infections  (ARI)  and  diarrhea  continue  to  be  the  most  frequent  diagnoses  at
BHUs  and  hospitals.  In  addition,  the  expanded  program  on  immunization  (EPI),  already  a
significant factor in the reduction of childhood morbidity and mortality, is considering introducing
a vaccine against Haemophilus influenza b but the role of this pathogen in the etiology of ARI in
Bhutan is unknown. Because of the cost of the vaccine, understanding the significance of this
pathogen is crucial prior to introducing the new vaccine.

38. While  access  to  allopathic  services  is  relatively  high,  access  to  traditional  medical
services  is  currently  limited  by  the  lack  of  indigenous  units  in  six  district  hospitals.  Improving
access to traditional medical services promotes social inclusion; those preferring these services
tend to be the poorer, older and more rural sectors of the population. Also, timely referral and
consultations  are  critical  to  providing  quality  care  including  access  to  higher  level  professional
care.  However,  in  Bhutan,  equitable  access  to  specialist  services  is  restricted  by  the  difficult
terrain  and  poor  transport  system.  Telecommunications  and  Internet  facilities  to  allow
consultation between the peripheral facility and the national referral hospital should be pursued
to  benefit  vulnerable  groups,  including  the  less  mobile,  old,  rural  population,  women,  and
children.

6. 

Other Emerging Challenges

39.
The  National  STD/AIDS  program  was  introduced  in  1988.  Alert  to  the  threat  of  AIDS,
despite the absence of known cases in the country, Bhutan developed its first medium-term plan
in  1990,  with  a  second  plan  in  1995.  By  the  end  of  1998,  there  were  only  nine  known  HIV-

6 PHC,  the  first  level  of  health  care  for  a  community,  generally  includes  preventive  services,  health  education  and
promotion, reproductive health services, efforts to improve nutrition, and basic curative care such as treatment for
diarrhea, acute respiratory tract infection, and tuberculosis. The World Health Organization also considers the first-
level referral hospital as part of the primary health care system.

 10

positive cases, all but one were contracted outside of the country and four had died. Although
the incidence of HIV/AIDS has remained relatively low, many of the prerequisite conditions for
the  introduction  and  spread  of  the  disease  are  in  evidence.  There  are  a  number  of  factors
suggesting that the potential for spread is significant: (i) Bhutan is surrounded by countries that
are experiencing an alarming spread of AIDS, and there is significant human traffic through its
porous  borders,  (ii)  STD  rates  are  at  least  7  percent;  much  of  this  is  in  the  adolescent  age
group, (iii) there is relatively low awareness of AIDS in the general population, (iv) commercial
sex workers and intravenous drug users appear to be increasing in number.

40.
Given the potential for a rapid spread in Bhutan now that the virus has been introduced,
the Government is implementing an aggressive prevention and control program. However, the
HIV/AIDS  surveillance  system,  a  crucial  component  of  any  control  program  is  weak,  and  the
multisectoral task force, which oversees the effort has been relatively inactive.

41.
In addition to the rate of growth, aging of the population will have a significant impact on
the demand for health services and the type of health services required. As the population ages
and  economic  development  continues,  there  will  be  a  shift  from  a  pattern  of  predominantly
infectious diseases to a pattern of chronic degenerative diseases. This shift will be exacerbated
by shifts in social and economic patterns, which will likely result in dietary changes, increased
consumption of alcohol and tobacco, and decreased physical activity. Chronic diseases such as
cancer,  diabetes,  heart  and  lung  disease,  stroke,  and  cirrhosis  will  therefore  become  more
prevalent with time. A recent report of the JDWNRH noted that 125 of the 545 patients sent for
out-of-country  treatment  during  the  financial  year  1998/1999  were  cancer  patients.  Cervical
cancer, the most common cancer among women in Bhutan, accounted for 7 percent of out-of-
country  referrals  in  1998.  Thus,  Bhutan  is  faced  with  the  dual  challenges  of  overcoming  the
residual  burden  of  communicable  diseases  and  the  growing  burden  of  noncommunicable
diseases, with its relatively limited financial resources.

C.

Government Objectives and Strategy

42.
During the Eighth Plan, the Government accords high priority to improving health care,
which  is  seen  as  the  key  to  promoting  the  country’s  social  and  economic  development.
Specifically,  the  Government  aims  to  (i)  intensify  population  planning  activities,  (ii) consolidate
and strengthen existing health infrastructure, (iii) promote self-reliance and sustainability in the
health  sector,  (iv)  strengthen  human  resource  development  for  effective  implementation  of
health  services,  (v)  enhance  the  quality  of  health  care  services,  and  (vi) extend  health  care
services  to  unreached  areas.  The  midterm  review  of  the  health  sector  during  the  Eighth  Plan
recommended that the Government continue its efforts to develop additional sources of health
financing, address the acute shortage of specialist doctors and technicians, and strengthen the
curative  and  diagnostic  capacity  for  timely  treatment  following  the  significant  achievements  in
preventive  care.  As  the  physical  expansion  of  health  infrastructure  is  consolidated,  the
Government is emphasizing improvements in the quality of health care.

43.
The  Government’s  long-term  vision  of  a  Bhutan  with  gross  national  happiness  as  the
ultimate  objective  is  articulated  in  the  document, Bhutan 2020, A Vision for Peace, Prosperity
and Happiness. Within this vision, the Government is committed to establishing a relevant and
cost-effective  health  care  delivery  system  based  on  the  PHC  approach,  which  effectively
delivers  health  care  services  to  all.  While  constant  efforts  will  be  made  to  deliver  free  health
care services on a cost-effective basis, the possibility of introducing some kind of cost-sharing
will be explored. The integrated PHC system will continue, with aspects of traditional medicine
complementary to formal health care phased into the system. The establishment of innovative

 11

sources  of  health  financing,  including  the  proposed  BHTF  is  seen  as  a  strategic  approach  to
ensuring sustainable financing of the Government’s vaccinations and essential drugs program.
Training  to  ensure  adequate  Bhutanese  personnel  are  available  to  staff  the  health  system  is
given  high  priority.  The  Government  highlights  population  growth  as  one  of  its  greatest
challenges; the centerpiece of its policies to address this challenge is reproductive health care,
including family planning.

D.

External Assistance to the Sector

44.
External assistance to the health sector is primarily provided by Denmark, India, United
Nations  Population  Fund  (UNFPA),  UNICEF,  and  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO)
(Appendix  4).  Under  the  current  five-year  plan,  Denmark,  through  the  Danish  International
Development  Agency,  supports  human  resource  development,  infrastructure  development,
health  systems  management  (support  to  planning,  the  HMIS,  epidemiology  and  research,
district management, and the framework for multisectoral collaboration), strengthening of health
services  (public  health  programs,  maintenance,  and  logistics),  information,  education  and
communication, and community participation. Extrabudgetary support is provided in the form of
three health advisers and funding of postgraduate training.

45.
India provides important assistance to the health sector. Its major contributions include
funding  for  the  National  Hospital  Program,  particularly  the  construction  and  expansion  of
JDWNRH, and the Mongar, Trashi Yangtse and Lhuentse hospitals. India provides funding for
the National Malaria Control Program. Off-budget funding consists of assistance to its hospitals,
and the financing and running of the India Bhutan Friendship Hospital. In addition India finances
undergraduate training through RCSC in the fields of medicine, nursing, and dentistry.

46.
UNICEF,  UNFPA,  and  WHO  support  is  largely  directed  to  public  health  programs.
UNICEF contributes for the construction and strengthening of ORCs, the EPI, safe motherhood,
nutrition, diarrheal disease and ARI control, the VHW program and preservice training of PHC
staff.  UNFPA  has  cofinanced  the  reproductive  health  program  and  the  information,  education
and  communication  for  health  program.  Although  providing  less  than  10  percent  of  total
financing in the health sector, WHO’s support is wide ranging and covers the areas of nutrition,
reproductive  health,  communicable  diseases,  mental  health,  community-based
EPI, 
rehabilitation,  human  resource  development,  health  promotion,  essential  drugs,  and  quality
assurance.

Support from the Japan International Cooperation Agency is provided in kind in the form
47.
of  equipment  and  vaccines.  It  contributes  between  $100,000  and  $120,000  worth  of  vaccines
and  cold  chain  equipment  to  the  health  sector,  through  UNICEF,  each  year.  The  European
Union  has  also  contributed  to  the  development  and  improvement  of  quality  assurance  for
traditional  and  indigenous  medicine.  The  German-Bhutan  Hospital  Foundation  financed  the
construction of the Punakha District Hospital and continues to provide TA through an expatriate
physician.

Consultations were held with major aid agencies at various stages of processing of the
48.
Program,  and  information  obtained,  especially  on  lessons  learned,  was  used  to  design  the
Program’s  policy  agenda.  Consequently,  the  proposed  loan  will  complement  assistance
provided  by  other  major  aid  agencies,  and  help  provide  an  enabling  policy  environment  to
enhance  the  effectiveness  of  the  various  health  programs  that  are  being  assisted  by  these
agencies.

 12

E.

ADB’s Operations and Strategy in the Sector

1.

Strategy

inclusiveness

49.
promoting  economic  growth  and  social 
in  human
development.  Therefore,  the  main  thrust  of  poverty  reduction  efforts  under  the  strategy  is  to
enable the Government’s commitment to be realized under the strategic theme of improving the

investments

50.
Investments in human development will be accompanied by policy support and capacity-
building activities to strengthen the Government’s capacity to expand the scope and quality of
traditional social services in line with the demands of an evolving economy. ADB’s strategy also
recognizes the need for the Government to strengthen its financial capacity to sustain its social
sector  programs.  In  the  health  sector,  there  is  a  need  to  put  the  long-term  financing  of  health
services  on  a  sustainable  footing  and  to  improve  the  quality  of  health  care  as  well  as  the
efficiency  with  which  such  health  care  is  provided.  The  proposed  ADB  loan  will  support  the
introduction  of  crucial  sector  reforms  to  enhance  the  effectiveness  of  the  country’s  health
programs  and  strengthen  the  Government’s  capacity  to  address  emerging  challenges  and
issues in the health sector. By facilitating the development of alternative approaches to ensure
sustainable financing in the health sector, the Program will contribute to improved governance,
particularly  in  domestic  resource  mobilization,  and  ultimately  contribute  to  overall  poverty
reduction  efforts.  More  focused  targeting  of  beneficiaries  will  be  facilitated  by  the  poverty
assessment study to be jointly conducted by the Government and ADB in 2000.

2.

Health Policy

51.
ADB’s  overall  approach  to  the  health  sector  is  to  assist  its  DMCs  ensure  their  citizens
have  broad  access  to  basic  preventive,  promotive,  and  curative  services  that  are  efficacious,
cost-effective,  and  affordable.  Drawing  upon  previous  ADB  interventions  in  the  health  sector
and  empirical  evidence  from  recent  research  and  observations,  the  strategy  will  focus  on
(i) improving  the  health  status  of  vulnerable  groups,  including  the  poor,  women,  children,  and
indigenous  peoples  with  an  emphasis  on  PHC;  (ii) investing  in  projects  and  programs  with
tangible  and  measurable  results;  (iii)  supporting  innovative  approaches,  including  new
approaches  to  health  care  financing  and  deployment  of  new  technologies;  (iv)  encouraging
DMC  governments  to  take  an  appropriate  and  activist  role  in  the  health  sector  through  much-
needed structural reforms; and (v) increasing the efficiency of health sector investments through
capacity-building, economic and sector work, and improved intersectoral linkages.

52.
Strong Government commitment and ownership are key to successful implementation of
structural reforms in the health sector. Pilot studies should be conducted to assess the impact of
such  user  charges  on  vulnerable  groups.  The  effective  delivery  of  health  programs  can  be
enhanced  through  more  efficient  planning  and  the  use  of  monitoring  systems  that  can  track
performance  targets.  New  institutional  mechanisms  for  quality  assurance  and  improved
management  information  systems  are  also  critical  for  strengthening  management  capacity  at
the central level, particularly when health services are decentralized.

 13

ADB still has limited experience in the use of a trust fund approach as a mechanism for
53.
ensuring  sustainable  financing  of  social  development  projects.7  However,  trust  fund  approach
was used to establish the Bhutan Trust Fund for Environmental Conservation (BTFEC) in 1992;
this was supported by a grant from the Global Environmental Fund and supervised by the World
Bank.  The  BTFEC  was  rated  as  satisfactory  in  the  Implementation  Completion  Report  of  the
World  Bank.  Key  lessons  learned  from  BTFEC  implementation  confirmed  that  the  successful
evolution  of  the  trust  fund  would  depend  on  (i)  the  existence  of  a  legal  framework  to
institutionalize  collaboration  between  financiers  and  recipients,  and  make  management
accountable  and  implementation  more  transparent;  (ii)  multistakeholder  or  aid  participation;
(iii) adequate start-up funding separate from investment income; (iv) relevant expertise in trust
fund  management;  and  (v)  the  recipient  government’s  strong  reputation  for  integrity  in
governance and demonstrated commitment to the program. Such lessons from the BTFEC have
been  used  by  the  Government  to  prepare  the  BHTF  as  an  innovative  sustainable  financing
facility.

A.

Rationale

V.

THE PROGRAM

Bhutan,  a  small  landlocked  country,  is  characterized  by  its  mountainous  terrain,  high
54.
population  growth  rate  and  limited  pool  of  skilled  human  resources,  and  economy  that  is  still
basically agricultural despite signs of industrial growth and diversification.  The Government has
always accorded high priority to human development and has achieved remarkable progress in
improving  the  country’s  social  indicators,  particularly  in  education  and  health.  Investments  in
human  development  will  however  remain  critical  to  (i) improving  the  social  well-being  of  its
predominantly rural population, which is widely dispersed across the country; and (ii) providing
the  much-needed  human  capital  to  support  a  growing  economy.  When  viewed  in  this  context,
the development of a healthy population provides the key to the country’s sustained economic
growth and poverty reduction efforts.

55. With human development serving as the primary objective of its development strategy,
the Government is seeking to ensure continued progress in improving the health status of the
population.  The  Government  recognizes  the  need  to  develop  (i)  a  comprehensive  policy
framework  to  address  structural  weaknesses  in  the  health  sector,  and  (ii)  a  more  forward-
looking blueprint to tackle new challenges and demands expected to emerge from the evolving
economy.  Specifically,  the  reform  agenda  is  aimed  at  enhancing  efficiency  in  resource
allocation;  ensuring  equitable  access  to  PHC  services;  and  strengthening  the  planning  and
management capacity, and regulatory framework for the health sector.

Sustainability  of  health  sector  financing  is  a  key  feature  of  the  Program;  other  sectors
56.
are bound to claim an increasing share of the Government budget as the economy expands and
the  population  continues  to  grow  rapidly.  It  is  inevitable  that  the  Government  must  explore
innovative and sustainable ways of financing a potential resource gap in the health sector and to
help reduce dependence on external assistance. In addition, the Government must protect and
strengthen  its  core  health  program  to  address  PHC  needs  of  vulnerable  groups,  particularly
women  and  children.  Thus,  in  this  connection,  the  Government  is  setting  up  the  BHTF  as  a
sustainable  financing  mechanism  to  meet  the  requirements  of  vaccines  and  essential  drugs,

7 The  trust  fund  approach  is  used  in  Loan  1693-TUV: Island Development Program,  for  $4  million,  approved  on

13 July 1999.

 14

which  are  key  components  of  PHC.  By  incorporating  policy  initiatives  that  will  ensure  a  more
focused  approach  in  addressing  equity  aspects  and  targeting  specific  vulnerable  groups,  the
Program  will  strengthen  the  partnership  between  the  Government  and  ADB  on  poverty
reduction.

57.
The  Health  Care  Reform  Program  encompasses  major  policy  measures  that  will
collectively promote a more enabling environment for the Government to pursue its ongoing and
future  health  programs.  The  Program  was  designed  in  consultation  with  other  major  aid
agencies,  and  its  implementation  is  expected  to  enhance  the  effectiveness  of  their  various
health programs. ADB’s timely intervention through the proposed program loan has already laid
the groundwork for institutionalizing a more coordinated approach among aid agencies, which at
present  rely  on  an  informal  monthly  luncheon  meeting  for  networking  to  coordinate  their
activities.8  With  its  sectorwide  coverage  and  inputs  from  other  aid  agencies,  the  Program  has
initiated  the  process  for  advancing  a  more  structured  and  coordinated  approach  among  aid
agencies  for  addressing  health  sector  issues,  which  are  expected  to  become  more  complex
over time in view of changing social, cultural, and economic circumstances.

B.

Objectives and Scope

58.
The  principal  objective  of  the  Program  is  to  provide  support  for  the  Government’s
comprehensive reform agenda for strengthening the health sector. Its scope includes five policy
priority areas: (i) develop sustainable financing for the health sector; (ii) strengthen capacity in
health  sector  management;  (iii)  strengthen  quality  assurance  and  public  health  regulatory
functions; (iv) adjust imbalances in human resources for health; and (v) strengthen PHC through
selective  PHC  interventions  and  expansion  of  priority  services.  The  Government’s  intention  to
implement the Program is summarized in the development policy letter (DPL), as presented in
Appendix  5.  Discussions  were  held  between  the  Government  and  the  ADB  on  the  various
specific policy reform measures that will be implemented as part of the Program. These policy
actions,  together  with  the  indicative  timing  of  their  implementation  are  highlighted  in  the
supporting policy matrix attached to the DPL in Appendix 5.

C.

Policy Framework and Actions

59.
The  policy  framework  and  its  specific  actions  included  in  the  Program  was  designed
through  a  participatory  process  that  involved  field  surveys,  focus  group  discussions,  and
consultations with other stakeholders, including the major aid agencies for the health sector in
Bhutan.  As  a  result,  the  reforms  and  specific  policy  initiatives  detailed  in  the  policy  matrix  are
consistent  with  the  Government’s  own  development  objective,  and  will  complement  the  health
programs  of  the  international  aid  community  in  Bhutan.  In  formulating  the  Program,  particular
attention was paid to equity and gender issues, and to the needs of specific vulnerable groups.
A  multisectoral  approach  was  used  to  identify  and  develop  some  of  the  intended  policy
measures, in view of the linkages between sectors and their impact on health.

8 The current practice has proved to be inadequate for coordinating the various discrete programs of the different aid
agencies as it falls short of addressing Bhutan’s health sector issues on a sectorwide or systemwide basis. This
shortcoming in aid coordination is highlighted in Report on the Evaluation of Danish Support to the Health Sector in
Bhutan 1990-1998 by Danish International Development Agency.

 15

1. 

Develop Sustainable Financing for the Health Sector

60.
The  high  population  growth  rate,  competing  global  and  domestic  demands  for  funding,
an economy in transition, and rising costs in the provision of social services, including health are
challenging the capacity of Bhutan to continue to provide free health and other medical services
to its citizens. The Government is aware that the lack of sustainable financing would derail its
various  health  programs  and  undermine  the  quality  of  health  care  in  the  country.  In  this
connection, it is adopting a two-pronged strategy to develop alternative sources of financing and
improve efficiency of resource use including cost containment.

61.
Bhutan’s current stage of economic development does not make privatization of health
care  delivery  feasible  given  its  limited  and  nascent  private  sector.  The  Government  remains
committed to make free health care accessible to all segments of society, and is responsible for
the  training  of  health  workers.  However,  the  Government  expects  a  wider  scope  for  private
financing  of  health  care  to  promote  sustainable  financing  and  to  encourage  rational  use  of
health  services.  It  intends  to  introduce  more  user  fees.  As  part  of  the  Program,  surveys  on
household  health  care  expenditure  and  attitudes  user  payment  will  be  conducted,  and
consultations with stakeholders on health services will be held initially to determine the scope of
health services to be deemed essential services. The findings of these surveys will be used as
the basis for designing a pilot study that will assess the feasibility of introducing user charges in
a phased manner, while ensuring that there will be no impact on access to such essential health
services (including those under traditional health care services) identified by the surveys. Based
on the information from this study, a user charge policy including a proposed fee structure will
be drawn up for public discussions prior to its implementation in the Ninth Five-Year Plan or the
Ninth  Plan  (FY2003-FY2007).  This  will  include  the  clear  identification  of  services  that  will  be
subject  to  user  charges;  their  respective  prices  (based  on  a  combination  of  analyses  of  cost,
and willingness and ability to pay); and, individuals or groups, who are to be exempt (partially or
fully)  from  paying  charges.  In  addition,  the  study  will  provide  an  assessment  of  the  potential
revenues,  the  impact  on  the  behavior  of  those  seeking  health  care,  and  the  capacity  to
implement the scheme.

62.
The  Program  will  also  explore  the  possibility  of  introducing  some  market  mechanisms
within the publicly financed system to secure additional efficiency gains. One option is to assess
the  feasibility  of  contracting  health-related  services  to  the  private  sector.  This  will  involve  a
market  analysis  for  the  private  sector  of  ancillary,  pharmaceutical,  and  other  medical-related
services to assess their ability to carry out services for the Government under contract, and will
include a close examination of capacity, licensing, regulation, and incentive structures.

63.
The Program will also assist the Government in mobilizing additional resources through
innovative  financing  mechanisms  for  the  health  sector.  The  Government  recently  established
the BHTF on the basis of a Royal Charter (Appendix 6). The trust fund mechanism for the health
sector was conceived with technical advice from WHO, following the Government’s experience
with the successful BTFEC, which was launched in 1992 with multi-donor funding support and
TA  from  several  external  sources.  The  BHTF  will  be  developed  as  a  sustainable  financing
mechanism  that  is  expected  to  generate  funds  to  cover  the  annual  expenditures  on  essential
drugs,  vaccines,  and  new  technologies,  which  are  expected  to  increase  from  $0.9  million  in
1999  to  $2.3  million  in  2008  (Appendix  7).  The  Government  has  given  its  assurance  that  the
BHTF  will  adopt  internationally  acceptable  practices  in  fund  administration  and  investment
management.

 16

In  addition,  the  Government  will  adopt  specific  policy  initiatives  to  improve  allocative
64.
efficiency  and  contain  costs,  while  ensuring  equity  in  the  provision  of  health  services.  Initially,
the Government will adopt a policy advocating the use of poverty incidence as one of the criteria
for  resource  allocation  to  ensure  equity  in  public  financing  of  health  services.  The  poverty
indicators  and  other  data  to  be  generated  by  a  new  HMIS  and  the  findings  of  the  joint
Government  and  ADB  poverty  assessment  exercise  will  then  be  used  to  allocate  health
resources  during  the  Ninth  Plan.  To  meet  future  challenges,  a  situation  analysis  of  chronic
degenerative  diseases  will  be  conducted  in  2001  to  gain  an  understanding  of  their  financial
implications for the health budget. A study of the projected need for and cost implications of out-
of-country training and medical treatment will also be carried out in 2001.

65.
The  Government  will  also  improve  its  financial  and  budgeting  procedures  to  address
inefficient  use  of  resources  in  the  health  sector.  This  will  involve  the  use  of  recurrent  cost
analysis on major capital investment as a standard planning tool in the health sector to facilitate
priority setting and decision making on the basis of cost-effectiveness.

2.

Strengthen Capacity in Health Sector Management

66.
The Government’s capacity to effectively manage, plan, and monitor its multiple health
programs  under  a  decentralized  system  has  been  constrained  by  shortage  of  staff  to  conduct
research  and  by  the  deficiencies  in  its  management  information  system.  To  overcome  these
shortcomings,  capacity-building  efforts  will  be  carried  out  through  the  introduction  of  a
comprehensive  strategic  planning  framework  for  relevant  health  programs.  For  instance,  the
Government has already taken steps to assess the relevance of integrating separately managed
health  programs  on  ARI  and  control  of  diarrheal  diseases  under  the  purview  of  a  program  for
integrated  management  of  childhood  illness.  In  addition,  the  Government  has  developed  a
restructuring  plan  to  strengthen  MOHE’s  PPD  through  the  proposed  creation  of  a  new
monitoring and evaluation section. This will follow the restructuring of MOHE into two separate
ministries in 2002. However, as part of the Program, the process of recruiting qualified staff will
be  started  as  soon  as  possible  to  ensure  that  such  staff  will  be  available  in  a  timely  manner
under  the  country’s  civil  service  system.  The  proposed  monitoring  and  evaluation  section  is
expected to play an important role in ensuring that the data and other reports submitted by the
district and village health offices are consistent and discrepancies are minimized.

67. While current MOHE plans have measurable, time-based indicators, there is difficulty in
tracking them due to deficiencies within the HMIS. Hence, the Program seeks to address these
problems  to  make  more  reliable,  useful,  and  timely  information  available.  The  Government  is
currently  reviewing  the  HMIS  with  the  assistance  of  the  Government  of  Denmark  and  it  is
expected  that  an  upgraded  HMIS  will  be  installed  by  2001.  This  improved  HMIS  will  help
(i) identify program beneficiaries more clearly and (ii) design appropriate programs to meet their
needs. With an upgraded HMIS, the Government will be able to ensure that its existing health
infrastructure will continue to serve a catchment area of an appropriate population size.

68.
Past  capital  investments  have  resulted  in  a  broad  network  of  hospitals  and  BHUs.
However, little attention was paid to developing a maintenance program to support the existing
health infrastructure. The Program will develop a routine inspection and maintenance program
for  health  facilities.  This  policy  initiative  is  particularly  important  as  the  Government  moves  to
consolidate  its  capital  investment  program;  promote  a  more  rational  use  of  health  facilities,
including  the  referral  system;  and  contain  overall  costs.  The  maintenance  program  should  be
incorporated  as  part  of  the  new  financial  management  and  planning  procedures  that  will  be

to  enhance  management  efficiency,  and  promote  greater 

transparency  and

3.

Strengthen Quality Assurance and Public Health Regulatory Functions

69.
Until recently, the organizational structure of MOHE did not include a central or focal unit
that  is  responsible  for  ensuring  the  quality  of  health  care  services  and  the  management  of
programs  and  activities.  Under  the  Program,  the  Government,  on  the  basis  of  a  review  of  its
management approach, created a quality assurance focal point within MOHE that will have the
mandate  to  promote  a  shift  to  more  results-based  management.  One  of  the  key  tasks  of  this
quality assurance center is to introduce the logistics system for the proper inventory of essential
drugs to monitor their availability, and usage, and expiration date.

70.
Regulatory function, an essential component of public health systems, remains relatively
undeveloped  in  Bhutan  and  hence  needs  to  be  strengthened.  As  part  of  the  Program,  a  focal
point  was  recently  established  within  MOHE  to  assume  responsibility  for  coordinating  public
health  regulation.  This  focal  point  will  (i)  ensure  that  health  sector  input  is  obtained  in  the
drafting  of  legislation  and  regulations  related  to  health,  and  enforcement  of  legislation  is
strengthened;  and  (ii)  be  responsible  for  disseminating  all  appropriate  public  health  legal
instruments. To achieve this task, a central repository was recently set up to compile, catalogue,
and update all existing and future legal instruments with a bearing on the health sector.

71.
The  creation  of  focal  points  for  quality  assurance  and  public  health  regulations  will
enable MOHE to draft important laws and regulations for public health in a more timely manner.
It will also help ensure that relevant health inputs are incorporated in other important legislation
drafted for other sectors such as industry. For instance, the lack of a focal point has hampered
the  legislation  for  creating  a  professional  body  for  accrediting  and  regulating  the  health
profession  with  a  goal  of  raising  professional  standards  and  enforcing  professional  codes  of
ethics. In this connection, the Program will facilitate the drafting of the legislation for the creation
of the Bhutan medical and health council for approval by the Council of Ministers in 2001. The
Government will also complete a situation analysis on the health-related and safety issues in the
industry and business sectors in 2001. This study will serve as the basis for future legislation for
an  Occupational  Health  and  Safety  Act  in  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan,  and  contribute  to  the
development  of  the  legal  framework  that  is  needed  in  line  with  economic  growth  and
diversification.

Specific regulations to regulate the marketing of breast-milk substitutes, and for tobacco,
72.
and  alcohol  control  will  also be put  in place. Currently, the Government itself has not enacted
any stringent regulation on the control of tobacco, and alcohol sales in the country, except for
subjecting  such  imports  (except  those  from  India)  to  the  maximum  duty  and  sales  tax  rates.
However,  many  districts  and  villages,  on  their  own  initiative,  have  banned  the  sale  of  tobacco
and discouraged its use in line with Buddhist religious belief. These regulations are expected to
promote  healthier  lifestyles  and  will  complement  the  Government’s  continuing  use  of
appropriate taxation policies to reduce the consumption of tobacco and alcohol, and to promote
public health.

73.
Environmental  health  will  also  be  strengthened  through  the  Program.  Residents,
particularly children, living close to health facilities, are exposed to health hazards arising from
the disposal of hospital waste. The Government will strictly enforce an improved system for the
proper  disposal  of  medical  waste  in  hospitals  and  other  health  facilities.  Environmental

 18

guidelines for urban and community development projects will also be adopted to contain their
adverse developmental impact on health.

4.

Adjust Imbalances in Human Resources for Health

74.
One of the major limitations to the provision of adequate health services in Bhutan has
been the lack of sufficient health workers of all categories. The Government has exerted efforts
to train more Bhutanese nationals to staff the various categories, including specialist positions
that are currently filled by expatriates. The Government recently carried out a review of gender
equity  to  address  the  concerns  of  female  health  staff  and  patients.  The  Government  will  also
encourage community participation in the delivery of basic health services by optimizing the role
of village health workers, who have made significant contributions.

75.
A major undertaking to adjust imbalances in human resources for health is to revise and
update the current Master Plan for Human Resources in Health (MPHRH) to reflect current and
projected personnel requirements in various disciplines, grade levels, and geographic areas. An
updated MPHRH will also address personnel issues more effectively, as personnel are the key
component  of  health  expenditures.  RCSC  also  uses  the  MPHRH  for  planning  investments  in
out-of-country  education;  thus  the  MPHRH  needs  to  present  a  more  accurate  assessment  of
health personnel requirements to ensure that resources are efficiently used. In this connection,
the  MPHRH  will  be  reviewed  and  updated.  The  Government  will  also  adopt  a  policy  to  help
ensure that all BHUs include female staff who can provide services to female patients. Female
staffing  in  health  units  is  particularly  critical  to  address  the  high  maternal  mortality  rate  in
Bhutan.
