D.

Social and Environmental Issues

79.
The Program will support the Government to continue its PHC program, which has the
poor,  women,  and  children  as  major  beneficiaries.  A  considerable  emphasis  on  provision  of
services to these vulnerable groups is demonstrated through the Government’s commitment to
maintain the share of recurrent expenditures on PHC at about 50 percent of total health sector
recurrent  expenditures.  The  commitment  of  the  Government  to  develop  the  traditional  health
care  system  as  part  of  publicly  provided  services  shows  their  concern  to  meet  the  perceived
needs and demands of the population. The Program will ensure that Government commitment
to both PHC and traditional health care will continue.

The  Program  includes  reform  measures  that  will  improve  resource  allocation,  while
80.
efficiency gains derived from the reforms will free up resources to address increasing access to
services  in  unserved  areas,  and  unmet  demands  for  health  care  such  as  maternal  and  child
health care. Appropriate policy measures through budgetary allocation have been incorporated
to ensure that any negative impact on the poor will only have a short-term effect of the reform
process. The policy reform to strengthen human resources will ensure gender equity in training
and  career  opportunities.  This  policy  will  lead  to  an  increase  in  the  number  of  female  health
workers,  help  break  down  barriers  to  women’s  access  to  health  care,  and  thus  improve  the
health status of women and children. The emphasis on reproductive health services, including
the establishment of more emergency obstetrical care facilities at district hospitals, will reduce
maternal mortality.

The  Program  will  also  yield  positive  environmental  benefits.  As  part  of  the  Program,
81.
environmental codes of practice will be developed to improve urban sanitation and solid waste
management, including medical waste from hospitals and health facilities. The Government will
strictly  enforce  regulations  covering  the  proper  disposal  and  treatment  of  medical  waste.  The
incorporation  of  environmental  health  aspects  in  the  preparation  of  urban  development
guidelines will lead to improved environmental quality.

A. 

Amount of Loan and Source of Funds

VI.

THE PROPOSED LOAN

The  Government  has  requested  that  the  ADB  provide  a  loan  of  $10.0  million  from  its
82.
Special  Funds  resources.  The  cost  of  implementing  the  necessary  key  policies  and  reform
measures is estimated at $10.0 million over five years (FY2001-FY2005), which will run through
the  first  half  of  the  Ninth  Plan  (FY2003-FY2007).  This  covers  mainly  the  development  of
sustainable health sector financing mechanisms excluding the capitalization requirements of the
BHTF;  budgetary  commitment  to  PHC;  capacity  building  for  health  sector  management,
including  the  adoption  of  new  management  planning  tools  and  techniques;  capacity-building
activities  in  quality  assurance  and  public  health  regulations;  and  improved  human  resource
development programs. The Government confirmed that the cost of the Program, to be incurred
over  five  years,  will  not  seriously  impair  its  comfortable  fiscal  position,  where  prudent  fiscal
management has enabled the Government to keep the budget deficit at a minimum. Moreover,

 20

some  funds  have  already  been  set  aside  to  help  capitalize  the  BHTF,  while  revenues  from
hydroelectric  projects  and  the  introduction  of  user  fees  for  nonessential  health  services  will
support its sound fiscal position.

B.

Interest, Maturity, and Utilization Period

83.
The proposed loan will have a repayment period of 24 years, including a grace period of
8 years. An interest rate of 1 percent will be charged per annum during the grace period and 1.5
percent per annum thereafter. The proposed loan is to be disbursed in two tranches. The first
tranche of $5.0 million will be made available upon loan effectiveness, while the second tranche
of $5.0 million will be made available following the Government’s compliance with the conditions
set  out  in  the  Loan  Agreement.  The  policy  matrix  in  Appendix  5  lists  the  conditions  for  the
release of the two tranches.

C.

Implementation Arrangements

MOHE will be the Executing Agency for the Program.9 MOHE will organize and chair an
84.
interministerial  steering committee (ISC) with representation from other Government ministries
and  offices  that  have  a  stake  in  the  policy  matrix.  These  will  include  the  Ministry  of  Finance,
Planning  Commission  Secretariat,  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry,  National  Environment
Commission,  and  Royal  Civil  Service  Commission.  The  ISC  will  serve  as  a  coordinating  and
monitoring mechanism, provide policy oversight in program implementation, and meet not less
than  once  every  quarter  before  all  second  tranche  conditions  are  satisfied.  The  ISC  will  be
supported by a program management unit (PMU) to be established within MOHE. It was agreed
that a director will head the PMU as program director. The PMU will be responsible for the day-
to-day monitoring of progress in meeting the policy actions required for the release of the two
tranches.  The  PMU  will  prepare  program  implementation  progress  reports  for  the  ISC.  The
progress  reports  will  be  provided  to  ADB  on  a  quarterly  basis.  The  organizational  structure  of
MOHE (Department of Health) is shown in Appendix 8.

D.

Procurement

The loan will finance the full foreign exchange costs, excluding local duties and taxes, of
85.
imports procured in and from ADB’s member countries, other than those specified in the list of
ineligible  items  and  those  items  financed  by  other  multilateral  and  bilateral  official  sources.
Procurement of eligible items under ADB’s loan will be based on normal commercial practices
for  procurement  by  the  private  sector,  or  standard  Government  procurement  procedures
acceptable to ADB for procurement by the public sector. In the case of goods commonly traded
on  international  commodity  markets,  procurement  will  be  undertaken  in  accordance  with
procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB.

E.

Disbursement

86.
The proceeds of the loan will be disbursed against a broad range of imports, subject to a
negative list of items, shown in Appendix 9. The loan will be disbursed until 30 September 2002
and  can  be  used  to  finance  eligible  expenditures  incurred  up  to  180  days  prior  to  the  date  of
loan  effectiveness.  On  the  basis  of  ADB’s  simplified  procedures  for  the  disbursement  of
program  loans,  the  Borrower  will  be  required  to  submit  with  each  withdrawal  request  a

9 Under the Government restructuring plan, MOHE is expected to be restructured into the Ministry of Health and the

Ministry of Education by 2002.

 21

certification  confirming  the  Borrower’s  compliance  with  the  following  formula  for  the  period
covered by the withdrawal request: for each year in which the proceeds of the loan are expected
to  be  disbursed,  the  value  of  the  country’s  total  imports  minus  (i) imports  from  nonmember
countries,  (ii)  ineligible  imports,  and  (iii)  imports  financed  under  other  official  development
assistance. This must be equal to or greater than the amounts expected to be disbursed during
the year. ADB will have the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy
of the Borrower’s certification.

F.

Counterpart Funds

87.
The  Government  has  indicated  that  the  proceeds  of  the  proposed  loan  will  be  used  to
help  meet  the  funding  requirements  of  the  BHTF.  The  Government  has  agreed  that  any  local
currency proceeds generated by the proposed loan (counterpart funds) will be used to support
the development of the health sector in general and the reforms to be initiated or implemented
under the policy framework of the Program.

G.

Monitoring and Tranching

88.
The proceeds of ADB’s loan will be released in two tranches when ADB is assured that
the  conditions  for  their  release  are  satisfied.  As  the  Government  has  complied  with  the  initial
actions designed as part of the Program, the first tranche of $5.0 million will be made available
upon  loan  effectiveness.  It  is  envisaged  that  the  second  tranche  for  $5.0  million  will  be
disbursed about one year after the release of the first tranche, subject to the fulfillment by the
Government of the specific conditions for its release, as detailed in the policy matrix, including
satisfactory progress in implementing the overall Program.

89.
Program  implementation  will  be  monitored  closely  by  the  Government  by  the  ISC
through its meetings and progress reports, and by ADB through its regular loan review missions.
Specific  performance  indicators,  based  on  existing  available  data,  have  been  developed  to
assist with monitoring; these will be improved as soon as the findings of the April 2000 health
sector  survey  are  compiled,  analyzed,  and  officially  released.  The  Government  has  agreed  to
use the annual health conference as part of the feedback mechanism for assessing the impact
of the Program on beneficiary groups, including the poor. Poverty and other socioeconomic data
generated by the Government-ADB poverty assessment study will be used to develop baseline
indicators to monitor the poverty impact of the Program.

A midterm review of the Program, including its impact on poverty and vulnerable groups,
90.
will be carried out jointly by the Government and ADB in 2003. A program completion report will
be  prepared  by  the  Government  not  later  than  three  months  following  program  completion  in
2005. The report will include an evaluation of the benefits of the Program based on the baseline
indicators developed through the data generated by the April 2000 health sector survey and the
Government-ADB poverty assessment study.

VII.

PROGRAM BENEFITS AND RISKS

A.

Benefits and Beneficiaries

The  Program  provides  a  long-term  strategic  vision  for  the  Government  to  improve  the
91.
health  status  of  the  Bhutanese  population  and  strengthen  its  capacity  to  cope  with  emerging
challenges  and  issues  in  the  health  sector  of  an  evolving  economy.  The  Program  focuses  on

 22

developing the software aspects of the health system in Bhutan to enhance the efficiency and
quality  of  health  care.  This  will  complement  the  massive  capital  investment  program  that  has
enabled  the  Government  to  provide  health  services  to  at  least  90  percent  of  the  population.
Concurrently,  the  Program  accords  continued  emphasis  to  the  PHC  system,  as  it  covers  a
package of basic services that have been proven to provide significant benefits to the vulnerable
groups,  including  the  poor,  women,  and  children.  Investments  in  health  enhance  human  well-
being,  and  will  generate  benefits  that  extend  to  increased  productivity,  increased  learning
capacity of school children, and increased efficiency in resource allocation; these free up limited
resources  that  would  otherwise  be  used  for  the  more  costly  treatment  of  disease.  Adoption  of
recurrent  cost  analysis  and  improved  financial  management  and  reporting  procedures  will
contribute  to  overall  efficiency  in  health  expenditures.  The  Program  is  thus  justified  on  the
grounds of efficiency and equity.

92.
Institutional  strengthening  is  another  major  benefit  that  will  be  generated  by  the
Program.  The  Program  will  accelerate  the  development  of  human  resources  needed  for  the
management and delivery of health services to the dispersed population. The Program will raise
the professional standards of health workers, strengthen the capacity to improve the quality of
health  care,  and  introduce  a  more  efficient  way  to  target  beneficiaries  of  the  various  health
programs. The Program will effectively address concerns over the increasing cost of health care
in  Bhutan.  The  Program  includes  specific  policy  measures  to  develop  more  sustainable  and
innovative mechanisms for health financing and to contain costs, which have been increasing at
an alarming rate and threaten the Government’s capacity to ensure adequate resources for its
health programs.

The  Program  also  directly  supports  the  development  of  a  policy  and  regulatory
93.
framework  to  strengthen  public  health  and  promote  healthy  behavior.  This  will  help  the
Government  reduce  the  burden  of  disease  through  more  public  regulations  and  an  intensified
information campaign aimed at reducing substance abuse (e.g., tobacco and alcohol) and use
of  betel  nut,  promoting  breast-feeding,  and  preventing  the  spread  of  STD/HIV.  Influencing
people’s choice of healthy behavior would have community-wide advantages and yield specific
benefits to specific vulnerable groups. For example, regulating the proper marketing of breast-
milk substitutes (or alternatively promoting breast-feeding) can have dramatic benefits for child
health  through  the  reduced  incidence  of  diarrhea.  The  introduction  of  occupational  health  and
safety guidelines will reduce the incidence of industrial accidents in the workplace.

94.
Although  the  Program  will  generally  lead  to  improved  health  status  of  the  entire
Bhutanese  population,  there  will  be  benefits  that  will  directly  accrue  to  specific  groups.  The
emphasis on PHC will directly benefit the poor, women, children, and rural communities that still
rely on indigenous or traditional medicine. Bhutan’s labor force will generally benefit with a safer
work  environment,  while  female  health  workers  will  be  granted  equal  opportunities  in  career
advancement and training.

B.

Poverty Reduction

Investments in health promote human development and help advance the goals of social
95.
and economic development. Improved health status of the population is an essential component
of  any  strategy  to  reduce  poverty.  For  the  poor  who  are  most  likely  to  be  involved  in  physical
labor as their main source of livelihood and income, good health is a most important asset and
the major determinant of earning capacity. However, the burden of disease is disproportionately
borne by the poor, who are more at risk to communicable diseases. In addition, the income of
the  poor  is  significantly  reduced  once  they  become  ill.  Economic  gains  from  investments  in

 23

health programs will thus be greater for the poor than for the nonpoor. This general observation
is also relevant in the case of the Program wherein policy measures and specific interventions in
PHC  will  contribute  to  the  improved  health  status  of  the  poor  and  accompanying  rise  in
productivity  and  income.  The  World  Bank  estimated  that  a  decrease  in  under-five  mortality  of
1.0 percent is associated with a 1.24 percent increase in per capita income growth.10

96.
The  poverty  impact  assessment  indicates  that  the  Program  was  developed  with
consideration  to  the  plight  of  vulnerable  groups  in  Bhutan  (Appendix  10).  The  assessment
concludes that the overall impact on the poor is strongly positive. The use of poverty indicators
as one of the criteria in resource allocation to ensure equity in public health financing will enable
the  Government  to  adopt  a  more  focused  approach  in  targeting  poverty  groups  in  its  health
programs. Specific PHC policy interventions will also reap substantial benefits for the poor. For
instance,  improving  access  to  emergency  obstetrical  care  centers  in  underserved  areas  and
assigning female health workers to BHUs will greatly benefit poor women who face higher risk
of  maternal  mortality.  Establishing  more  indigenous  medicine  units  at  district  hospitals  will
improve access to health care for the rural poor who continue to embrace traditional medicine.
Strengthening  of  the  HIV/AIDS  surveillance  system  will  be  of  advantage  to  women  who  are
biologically more vulnerable to STD and HIV infection, and to the poor who are generally more
likely  to  be  involved  in  commercial  sex.  The  study  on Haemophilus influenza b vaccine  for  its
possible inclusion in the EPI is a move that will eventually benefit children since ARI is one of
the leading causes of infant mortality in Bhutan.

C.

Risks and Safeguards

The Program was formulated on the basis of the Government’s continued commitment
97.
to  accord  priority  to  the  health  sector,  including  budgetary  and  human  resources.  Any  major
change  in  the  policy  direction  of  the  Government,  caused  by  weakening  macroeconomic  and
fiscal  position  could  delay  the  implementation  of  policy  actions  as  originally  intended.  Policy
discussions  between  ADB  and  the  Government  at  the  ministerial  level  have  revealed  that  the
country’s  development  policy,  anchored  on  the  principles  of  social  justice  and  equity,  will
continue  to  accord  budgetary  priority  to  the  social  sectors,  including  health.  The  continuing
support  from  the  major  external  funding  in  Bhutan’s  health  programs  will  provide  another
safeguard against any derailment of the Program due to an economic downturn.

98.
Various  Government  ministries  and  offices  are  involved  in  implementing  the  Program,
given its intersectoral nature. The lack of coordination of these ministries could delay program
implementation.  The  creation  of  the  ISC  with  representation  from  all  concerned  ministries  to
provide  policy  oversight  and  coordination  will  help  minimize  this  risk.  The  PMU  at  MOHE  will
provide  technical  support.  Regular  ADB  review  missions  will  also  support  these  coordination
efforts.

99.
There  will  be  some  risks  associated  with  implementing  specific  policy  measures.  The
introduction of user fees may serve as a barrier and deter would-be patients, including the poor,
from  seeking  health  services.  To  minimize  this  risk,  the  Government  has  agreed  to  conduct  a
pilot study, including a willingness-to-pay component, to ensure that such a policy measure will
be  limited  to  nonessential  services  and  will  have  no  adverse  impact  on  access  to  essential
services.  Prior  to  the  introduction  of  such  user  fees,  the  Government  will  conduct  intensive
marketing  and  educational  campaigns  to  explain  the  need  to  develop  sustainable  financing

10 Cited in ADB. 1999. Policy for the Health Sector. Manila.

 24

mechanisms.  Various  media  will  be  used  and  public  discussions  will  be  held  with  community
groups.  Full  information  on  the  proposed  fee  structure  will  be  provided  during  the  information
campaign. In addition, exemption and adjustment mechanisms and monitoring methods will be
incorporated in the user fee policy.

100.
Finally,  there  is  the  risk  that  the  BHTF  may  not  be  able  to  achieve  its  revenue  targets
due  to  poor  market  performance,  a  risk  that  applies  to  all  trust  funds.  In  addition  to  the
engagement  of  a  professional  fund  manager,  the  Government  will  adopt  other  prudent
measures  to  safeguard  its  investment  in  the  BHTF.  These  include  (i)  the  setting  of  clear
guidelines in the Royal Charter and in its contract with the fund manager to govern the permitted
level of risk and nature of investments, (ii) the use of appropriate international benchmarks as
the  basis  for  measuring  the  fund  manager’s  performance,  and  (iii)  the  setting  of  limits  on  the
extent for drawing down the principal of the BHTF.

The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  BHTF  will  be  exempted  from  income  tax,

activities under the health sector.

additional  pressure  on  health  care  financing,  where  recurrent  expenditures  have  been
rising  substantially.  This  high  population  growth  rate  will  eventually  erode  economic
growth  and  poverty  reduction  by  restricting  savings  and  investment.  Public  health
concerns  have  also  emerged  with  regard  to  use  of  alcohol  and  betel  nut,  increased
smoking and the potential spread of HIV/AIDS. Effectively addressing these challenges
will require adequate financial resources, improved management practices, strengthened
human resources for health and effective public health regulations to be enforced.

As stated in the Eighth Five-Year Plan (1997-2002), the RGoB accords high priority to
improving  health  care,  which  is  seen  as  the  key  to  promoting  the  social  and  economic
development of the country. Specifically, the Government aims to (i) intensify population
planning  activities;  (ii)  consolidate  and  strengthen  existing  health  infrastructure;
(iii) promote  self-reliance  and  sustainability  in  the  health  sector;  (iv)  strengthen  human
resource  development  for  effective  implementation  of  health  services;  (v)  enhance  the
quality  of  health  care  services;  and  (vi)  extend  health  care  services  to  those  unreached
areas.  It  is  the  intention  of  the  RGoB  to  address  long-term  strategic  issues  through  a
health care reform program.

The  proposed  health  care  reform  program  (the  Program),  which  will  run  during  a  five-
year period (2000-2005) has five key objectives: (i) developing sustainable financing in
the  health  sector,  (ii)  strengthening  capacity  for  health  management,  (iii)  strengthening
quality  assurance  and  public  regulatory  functions,  (iv)  adjusting  imbalances  in  human
resources for health, and (v) strengthening primary health care (PHC). The Program will
include  specific  reform  measures  to  address  priority  issues  in  health  service  planning,
monitoring and implementation as shown in the attached Policy Matrix. We believe that
the  proposed  program  will  contribute  to  the  realization  of  the  vision  of  a  Bhutan  2020
when  access  to  health  care  is  no  longer  an  issue  and  when  a  strong  and  self-financing
health  system  has  been  developed  to  promote  human  development  objectives  including
increased productivity and poverty reduction.

1.

Developing Sustainable Financing for Health Care

Given  the  recent  substantial  investment  in  health  infrastructure  and  expected  rise  in
recurrent expenditures, the RGoB is aware of the urgent need to put long term financing
of health care services on a sustainable footing and ensure that the expansion of primary
health care services for all Bhutanese continues. In this connection, the RGoB is adopting
a  two-pronged  strategy  of  increased  resource  mobilization  and  increased  efficiency  in
resource use including cost containment. On the basis of our timetable for reform agenda,
the following major policy initiatives will be implemented in 2000.

(i)

The  Government  will  initially  approve  a  policy  paper  advocating  the  need  to
expand  user  charges  for  selected  health  care  services  through  a  pilot  study.  The
policy  paper  will  be  based  on  the  findings  of  surveys  on  current  user

2

 (ii)

(v)

39

Appendix 5, page 3

charges  in  hospitals  and  household  income  and  expenditure  patterns  on
health  care  and  discussions  with  stakeholder  groups.  The  policy  paper  will
be  the  basis  for  launching  a  pilot  study  by  end  of  2000  that  will  assess  the
feasibility  of  the  expansion  of  user  charges  on  selected  nonessential  health
services.  In  carrying  out  the  pilot  study,  the  Ministry  of  Health  and
Education (MOHE) will assess their impact on use of health services as well
as  studying  health-seeking  behavior  to  identify  other  mechanisms  to
encourage rational use of health services and to ensure that there will be no
impact on the access to essential services, particularly among the poor.

The  Bhutan  Health  Trust  Fund  (BHTF)  will  be  legally  established  through
the  issuance  of  a  Royal  Charter.  The  BHTF  will  be  developed  as  a
sustainable  financing  mechanism  that  is  expected  to  generate  funds  to
cover  the  annual  expenditure  on  essential  drugs,  vaccines  and  new
technologies.  It  is  important  to  note  that  the  focus  of  the  BHTF  is  on
primary  health  care  (PHC)  and  will  support  the  expanded  program  on
immunization and reproductive health, of which women and children are the
prime beneficiaries.

7.

In  addition,  more  policy  initiatives  will  be  adopted  in  2001.  Some  of  these
will be based on the findings of the studies mentioned above. These include
the following:

A  policy  paper  advocating  the  use  of  poverty  incidence  as  one  of  the
criteria  for  resources  allocation  to  ensure  more  equitable  access  to  health
services  will  be  completed.  Subsequently,  poverty  indicators  based  on
the  data  generated  by  a  new  health  management  information  system
(HMIS)  and  the  findings  of  the  joint  RGoB/ADB  poverty  assessment
exercise  will  be  used  as  one  of  the  planning  inputs  for  allocating
resources in the health sector during the Ninth Five-Year Plan.

(vi)

Situation  analysis  completed  on  chronic  degenerative  diseases.  To  the
extent  possible,  we  will  attempt  to  project  the  burden  of  disease  and  its
financial implications for the health budget.

(vii) On the basis of the pilot study, we will develop a proposed structure of user
charges  on  additional  health  services  and  the  institutional  mechanisms
needed  to  administer  these  user  charges.  Public  discussions  will  be  held

To enhance the efficient use of resources in the health sector, the MOHE will
now be using recurrent cost analysis in order to project the impact of major
capital investment projects on recurrent budget. This will become a standard
planning tool to improve the priority setting and decision-making process on
the basis of cost-effectiveness.

2.

Strengthening Capacity for Health Sector Management

8.

9.

The  RGoB  also  recognizes  the  need  to  overcome  weaknesses  that  relate  to
deficiencies  in  planning,  management,  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  of  public
health  policies  and  programs.  Capacity-building  efforts  will  be  carried  out  through
the  introduction  of  a  comprehensive  strategic  planning  framework  for  health
programs in 2000. The MOHE has also developed a restructuring plan for its Policy
and Planning Division, which will be strengthened through the proposed creation of
a new M&E section. The identification and training of adequate staff for recruitment
will  also  be  completed  in  2001  in  order  to  ensure  that  qualified  staff  will  be  made
available  under  our  civil  service  system  for  the  restructured  Policy  and  Planning
Division immediately after the bifurcation of the MOHE into the Ministry of Health
and the Ministry of Education which is proposed to take place in 2002.

Management  and  planning  of  health  facilities  will  also  be  enhanced  through  the
adoption  of  a  standard  health  facility  maintenance  program.  The  adoption  of  new
financial management procedures in 2001 will also promote greater transparency and
accountability.

10. Monitoring  and  research  capacity  of  the  MOHE  will  also  be  strengthened.  While
current  plans  in  the  MOHE  have  measurable,  time-based  indicators,  there  is
difficulty  in  tracking  them  due  to  deficiencies  within  the  Health  Management
Information  System  (HMIS).  Hence,  the  problems  with  HMIS  will  be  addressed
under  the  program  such  that  more  reliable,  useful  and  timely  information  will  be
made  available.  The  RGoB  expects  to  install  an  upgraded  HMIS  by  2001.This
improved  HMIS  will  help  in  identifying  program  beneficiaries  more  clearly  and  in
designing appropriate programs to meet their needs.

3.

Strengthening  Quality  Assurance  and  Public  Health  Regulatory
Functions

11.

The  RGoB  also  recognizes  the  need  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  MOHE  to
ensure  the  quality  of  health  care  services.  In  view  of  this,  the  RGoB  has
reviewed  its  management  approach  and  will  soon  establish  a  “focal  point”

4

 12.

13.

14.

41

Appendix 5, page 5

within the MOHE which has the responsibility for “Quality Assurance” with respect
to both the delivery of services and the management of activities and programs. This
“focal point”, will have the mandate to promote a shift towards more “results based”
management.  A  review  of  the  logistics  for  the  proper  inventory  of  essential  drugs
will be carried out as part of this exercise.

Regulatory  function,  an  essential  component  of  public  health  systems,  remains
relatively undeveloped in Bhutan and hence needs to be strengthened. A focal point
will  also  be  established  within  the  MOHE  in  2000  to  assume  responsibility  for
coordination  of  public  health  regulation.  This  focal  point  will  ensure  that  health
sector  input  is  obtained  in  the  drafting  of  legislation/regulation  that  is  related  to
health  and  enforcement  of  regulations  is  strengthened  and  will  also  be  responsible
for  the  dissemination  of  all  appropriate  public  health  legal  instruments.  To  achieve
this  task,  a  central  repository  will  be  set  up  to  compile,  catalogue  and  update  all
existing and future legal instruments with a bearing on the health sector.

The creation of focal points for quality assurance and public health regulations will
enable  the  MOHE  to  facilitate  the  drafting  of  important  laws  and  regulations  for
public health. We expect that the draft legislation on the Bhutan Medical and Health
Council will be approved by the Council of Ministers in 2001 and submitted to the
National  Assembly  for  its  consideration  soon  after.  We  also  intend  to  complete  a
situation  analysis  on  occupational  health  and  safety  issues  as  the  basis  for  future
legislation  in  the  ninth  Five-Year  Plan.  Specific  regulations  on  the  marketing  of
breast milk substitutes and for tobacco and alcohol will also be put in place in 2001.
Environmental  codes  of  practice  to  improve  urban  sanitation  and  solid  waste
management, including an improved system for the proper disposal of medical waste
in hospitals and other health facilities will also be adopted in 2001.

4.

Adjusting Imbalances in Human Resources for Health

One of the major limitations to the provision of adequate health services in Bhutan
has  been  the  lack  of  sufficient  health  workers  of  all  categories.  The  RGoB  has
exerted  efforts  to  train  more  Bhutanese  nationals  to  staff  the  various  categories,
including specialist positions that are currently filled in by expatriates. A review of
gender equity to address the concerns of female health staff and patients is expected
to  be  completed  by  September  2000.  The  RGoB  will  also  review  the  existing
practices  with  regard  to  the  training  and  use  of  village  health  workers.  The  RGoB
will  continue  to  encourage  community  participation  in  the  delivery  of  basic  health
services by optimizing the role of village health workers who have made significant
contributions.

15.

A  major  undertaking  to  adjust  imbalances  in  human  resources  for  health  is
to  revise  and  update  the  current  Master  Plan  for  Human  Resources  in  Health

5

 42

Appendix 5, page 6

issues  more  effectively,  as  personnel  are 

(MPHRH)  to  reflect  more  current  and  projected  personnel  requirements  in
various  disciplines,  grade  levels  and  geographic  areas.  An  updated  MPHRH  will
also  address  personnel 
the  key
component  of  health  expenditures.  The  Royal  Civil  Service  Commission
(RCSC)  also  uses  MPHRH  for  planning  investments  in  overseas  education;  thus,
the  MPHRH  needs  to  present  a  more  accurate  situation  of  the  health  personnel
requirements  to  ensure  that  resources  are  efficiently  used.  In  this  connection,  the
MPHRH  will  be  reviewed  and  updated  in  2001.  The  RGoB  will  also  implement
a  policy  to  ensure  that  all  basic  health  units  will  include  female  staff  who  can
provide  services  to  female  patients.  This  will  also  help  promote  more  antenatal
visits  to  health  centers  and  reduce  the  high  maternal  mortality,  particularly  in  the
rural areas.

5.

Strengthening Primary Health Care (PHC)

To  demonstrate  our  continuing  commitment  to  primary  health  care,  the  RGoB
will  adopt  policies  to  strengthen  PHC  through  selective  interventions  and  the
expansion  of  priority  services  to  benefit  vulnerable  groups  and  underserved  areas.
Among  these  initiatives  is  to  reactivate  the  Multisectoral  Task  Force  on  STD/HIV
issues  to  ensure  its  active  participation  in  promoting  political  and  social
awareness on such issues and help strengthen the HIV/AIDS surveillance system.

In order to ensure effective delivery of PHC, the RGoB will ensure that for each of
the  fiscal  year  during  Program  period  (2000-2005),  the  recurrent  expenditures  as  a
percentage  share  of  total  health  budget  will  not  fall  below  the  level  of  1998/1999.
Within  the  total  health  recurrent  expenditures,  the  share  of  recurrent  budget
allocated  to  PHC  throughout  the  Program  duration  will  not  be  allowed  to  fall
below  50  percent  to  support  the  implementation  and  operations  of  selected  PHC
interventions.  These  will  include  (i)  increasing  the  number  of  hospitals  providing
comprehensive  reproductive  health  services,  including  emergency  obstetric  care
and clinical family planning, from four to eight, in under-served areas and (ii) a tel
-medicine  pilot  project  that  links  the  Mongar  Regional  Referral  hospital  with  the
JDWNRH in Thimphu. It is hoped that these measures will make health care more
accessible.

In addition, to strengthen our expanded immunization program, we will carry out a
study to determine the importance of Haemophilus influenza b in the epidemiology
of  acute  respiratory  tract  infections.  The  RGB  will  also  establish  six  more
indigenous  units  so  that  all  district  hospitals  will  have  such  units  by  2002.  This  is
in  line  with  the  policy  objective  to  provide  traditional  health  care  to  the  segment
of society seeking such type of health care.

In  order  to  implement  the  Program  in  a  timely  and  effective  manner,  we  have  set
up  an  inter-ministerial  steering  committee  (ISC)  to  provide  policy  oversight  and  to
monitor  and  co-ordinate  the  implementation  progress  of  the  various  policy
initiatives.  The  ISC  will  be  supported  by  a  Program  Management  Unit  (PMU)  to

BHUTAN HEALTH TRUST FUND

I.

Objectives and Strategy

The  Bhutan  Health  Trust  Fund  (BHTF)  is  a  Government  initiative  to  support  the
1.
sustainability  of  primary  health  care  services  through  the  continued  supply  of  vaccines  and
essential  drugs.  For  the  most  part,  the  immunization  program  is  currently  financed  through
donations  in  kind  from  the  international  community.  The  Japan  International  Cooperation
Agency  has  committed  over  half  of  the  required  funding  each  year  until  2002.  After  this  date
there  is  no  committed  funding  for  the  expanded  program  for  immunization  (EPI)  program  and
alternative, sustainable sources of funding were explored to ensure its ongoing implementation.
One  of  the  options  considered  was  the  creation  of  a  trust  fund  with  investment  sufficient  to
generate  funds  to  cover  the  annual  expenditure  on  essential  drugs  and  vaccines.  Technical
advice was initially provided by the World Health Organization (WHO); the existing Bhutan Trust
Fund for Environmental Conservation (BTFEC) was used as a model for setting up the BHTF.

II. 

Status of the BHTF

2.
In drawing lessons from the successful BTFEC, the BHTF was legally established under
a  Royal  Charter  in  August  2000,  following  which  a  board  of  directors  and  a  secretariat  were
constituted.  The  Government  has  been  actively  promoting  the  BHTF  among  potential  donors
and is committed to match all aid grants to the BHTF. To date, the Government has been able
to  raise  a  total  of  about  $2.94  million  (including  interest  earnings)  for  the  BHTF  from  its  own
resources and from contributions from other sources as indicated in Table A7.1.

Table A7.1: Contributions to the Bhutan Health Trust Fund (Excluding interest earned)

3.
The Government has committed to further deposit $239,823 to the BHTF, the balance of
its initial $2.0 million commitment. The proposed ADB program loan will assist the Government
in  augmenting  its  contribution  to  the  BHTF,  by  initially  achieving  the  minimum  capital
requirements  of  at  least  $5.0  million,  for  which  the  BHTF  can  become  operational.  The
Government plans to have the BHTF attain a desired capitalization target of $24 million through
additional external contributions, which will be matched by the Government on one-to-one basis
from  its  own  resources  and  income  generated  by  the  BHTF  as  appropriate.  The  $24  million
capitalization would enable the Government to help cover the projected total requirements of the
vaccinations and essential drugs programs estimated to reach $2.3 million in 2008 (Table A7.2).

 61

Appendix 7, page 2

III.

Management and Administration of the BHTF

4.
A secretariat, comprising a project director, and required staff, is responsible for the day-
to-day activities, and for implementing board decisions. In addition, an advisory committee will
be established to provide advice to the board and the secretariat, and will be convened on an ad
hoc basis when it is considered necessary to review the progress of the BHTF.

5.
The BHTF will be established as a 501(c)4 or similar status in the United States (US) or
host nation to ensure its exemption from tax on earnings. The feasibility of this must be explored
further.  It  is  believed  that  as  a  social  welfare  organization,  the  BHTF,  like  the  BTFEC,  should
fulfill the necessary criteria to achieve this status. An annual audit of the BHTF will be carried
out  by  the  Royal  Audit  Authority  and  an  international  accounting  firm,  on  request  of  the
management board.

6.
An  international  fund  manager  will  be  contracted  to  manage  the  investments  to
guarantee  an  income  of  a  certain  level  above  US  inflation,  taking  into  account  international
benchmarks  for  investment  revenues  in  similar  funds.  Board  members  will  include  individuals
with the requisite skills to review the progress of the BHTF. The quarterly reports to be provided
by the program monitoring unit to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will include a report on
the performance of the BHTF and its investments, including the use of proceeds of income from
its  investment.  Any  changes  proposed  to  the  Royal  Charter  during  the  Program  period  will  be
carried  out  after  prior  consultation  with  ADB.  In  the  event  of  termination  or  dissolution  of  the
BHTF,  the  remaining  assets  of  the  trust  fund  will  be  used  first  to  meet  the  objectives  of  the
BHTF, any remaining balance will be used to finance related development activities under the
health  sector  in  Bhutan.  Annual  reports  of  the  BHTF,  which  will  include  audited  financial
statements, will be submitted to ADB.

Appendix 10, page 1

POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

1.
The United Nations Development Programme rank Bhutan 142nd among 174 countries
in  terms  of  human  development.  This  is  the  lowest  ranking  of  all  South  Asian  developing
member countries. Gross national product per capita is $586 and 85 percent of the Bhutanese
population  still  reside  in  rural  areas.  The  dependence  on  subsistence  agriculture  is  evident  in
the  low  level  of  monetization  and  the  large  contribution  agriculture  plays  in  gross  domestic
product. The Government is committed to economic development with an emphasis on equity;
this has led to commendable investments in health and education. The program goals fall in line
with  these  tenets,  looking  to  reform  to  strengthen  health  care  delivery  and  ensure  sustainable
sources of financing for primary health care (PHC) in the long term. Implicit in development of
the  Program  has  been  concern  for  the  poor,  and  each  of  the  program  outputs  serves  this
vulnerable  group.  The  main  program  outputs  therefore  contain  measures  aimed  at  improving
access  to  health  services  and  contributing  to  bettering  health  status  for  all.  A  description  of
impact on poverty of each of the program elements follows.

A.

Develop Sustainable Financing for the Health Sector

2.
Financing reform of the health sector will be achieved by developing additional methods
of  finance—user  charges  and  the  Bhutan  Health  Trust  Fund  (BHTF).  The  net  increase  of
resources will be translated into an increased subsidy for the poor if the commitment to PHC is
maintained  and  the  user  charge  strategy  is  defined  in  a  way  that  does  not  have  an  adverse
impact on health service utilization by the poor. Increased efficiency and cost containment in the
health  sector,  within  the  context  of  maintained  expenditures,  will  free  up  resources  for  more
cost-effective allocation and an increased ability to meet the needs of unserved areas, currently
unmet demands and human resource strengthening. This will lead to a net increase in subsidy
to the poor.

B.

Strengthen Capacity in Health Sector Management

3.
Improved  quality  and  management  capacity  will  lead  to  better  health  services  for  all,
including the poor. Thus as long as the budget allocation is maintained, there will be a net gain
for  the  poor.  Management  capacity  improvements  may  also  lead  to  efficiency  gains,  in  which
case the net transfer of subsidies to the poor will also increase.

C.

Strengthen Quality Assurance and Public Health Regulatory Functions

4.
If  the  cost  of  new  regulations  are  in  excess  of  the  cost  savings,  this  will  translate  to
higher prices for goods and services. In addition, if regulation is too costly, production may shift
to  other  countries  in  the  region,  having  an  adverse  affect  on  economic  growth  and
diversification.  In  terms  of  impact  on  the  poor,  this  is  partially  offset  by  increased  access  to
quality, well-regulated health and other services. In the long run, regulation, if appropriate, will
lead  to  economic  growth  through  cost  savings  due  to  better  health  status  and  resulting
increased  production  levels.  In  addition,  these  gains  to  the  poor  include  reduction  in
occupational  and  environmental  health  hazards,  and  related  ill  health  and  associated  costs.
Strengthening of quality assurance of health programs will also translate to improved quality of
health care for the poor.

 66

Appendix 10, page 2

D.

Adjust Imbalances in Human Resources for Health

5.
Revising  and  updating  the  human  resources  master  plan  and  ensuring  equal
opportunities for men and women in the health care career path will strengthen human resource
development. The former is expected to lead to increased efficiencies in the health care system.
The latter will result in increased numbers of women working at the basic health unit (BHU) level
and  below.  In  turn,  this  will  break  down  barriers  to  women’s  access  to  health  care,  improving
health status, and hence, financial stability.

E.

Strengthen  PHC  Through  Selective  Interventions  and  Expansion  of  Priority
Services

Ensuring equity in health service delivery will be achieved by maintaining the budgetary
6.
commitment to health services, and in particular PHC. Alongside this financing, regulatory and
management reform must ensure that the poor are protected by ensuring essential services are
still free of cost, and where charges are introduced appropriate exemption mechanisms are in
place  to  protect  the  poor.  Selective  PHC  interventions  are  especially  designed  to  meet  the
health needs of vulnerable groups, including the poor, women, and children. Thus, emphasis on
PHC will have substantial benefits for the poor.

In summary, the Program will benefit the poor as long as conditions to protect the poor
7.
population are met with regards to the user charge strategy. Any negative impact on the poor,
resulting  from  other  elements  of  the  Program,  is  predicted  to  be  a  short-term  effect  of  reform
and caused by higher prices as a result of indirect taxation and public health regulation. As well
as increasing the direct subsidy to the poor through improved resource allocation, the efficiency
gains derived from the reforms will free up resources to increase access to services in unserved
areas;  meet  unmet  demands  for  health  care,  such  as  maternal  and  child  health  care;  and
strengthen human resources. Thus, the overall impact is strongly positive.
